issue.title: Latent distribution test size
issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
- Fixes #222 
- Fixes #358  
- Fixes #363 
- Fixes #370  (the 0 permutations part; for change in api see #375)

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
For #222:
- introduced the sampling from the asymptotic distribution of the ase correction
- added corresponding unit tests

For #358:
- No longer raises an exception with directed inputs
- Added corresponding tests

For #363:
- added the capability to use sklearn kernels (for hsic test, which is same as mmd) 
- raising warnings when distance used with hsic or kernel used with hsic
- added corresponding unit tests

For #370:
- No longer raises an exception with 0 bootstraps
- fit_predict left unchanged (returns a nan if used with 0 bootstraps)

Miscellaneous:
- removed gaussian medial kernel implementation and instead importing it from hyppo
  - avoid code duplication 
  - that version is parallelizable
- the default changed from "dcorr" + "euclidean" to "hsic" + "gaussian". reasoning behind the change:
  1. in theory, dcorr and hsic are almost the same, except that one uses distances and the other uses kernels (they are in fact, equivalent for some choices of distances and kernels, as per distances and kernels EE paper). in practice "dcorr" + "euclidean" and "hsic"+"gaussian" either perform very similarly, or "hsic" has an advantage (see: https://mgc.neurodata.io/tutorials/independence/indep_power.html ) .
  2. Minh's nonpar paper, which proves the convergence uses Gretton's MMD (which is same as "use k-sample transform + hsic"), rather than Energy (which  is same as "use k-sample transform + dcorr"). i wouldn't be surprised if it is possible to prove a similar thing for Energy as well, but no one has yet.
  3. the test that we used to have before adding hyppo backend (MMD) is the same as "hsic" + "gaussian". obviously because of implementation differences, results of old sims won't be reproduced exactly, even when seeded, but this is the closest possible choice to be "backward-compatible"
  4. all my simulations for the size correction paper were performed with MMD. in theory, they should transfer to, say, dcorr and maybe other tests, but i am most confident in this specific choice.
- added an option to use workers=-1 to specify all possible threads (consistent with hyppo and sklearn)
- passing workers to sklearn's distances and kernels

#### Any other comments?
Does not address #177

issue.title: returning test statistic in LDT
issue.body:
some practitioners (read: Vince, cep) only care about the test statistic and not the p-value. obviously one can still extract it if they perform the full test. however, that wastes time and resources. one can set the number of iterations to 1 to minimize that, but we can still do less. i propose to allow the number of permutations to be set to 0 (hyppo allows that, so really it is just a change in argument check). i am happy to do this, but:

this brings up the following questions: what should be happening to the fit_predict in that case? should it return the test statistic instead? or the p-value of 1? or NaN? should we be raising warnings?

and on a larger scale: should we really have this API? should fit predict return p-value, or a tuple of a p-value and a test statistic, like many other tests in python? furthremore, should it really be a class? once again, most tests in python that i have seen (scipy, statsmodels) are functions, not classes.

issue.title: UnmatchedTest tutorial should be on an unmatched example

labels.name: ndd
labels.description: tasks that may be appropriate for Neuro Data Design course

issue.body:
I don't like how the exact same example I used for the MatchedTest tutorial was used for Unmatched also. We should:
- [ ] explain when one would use unmatched
- [ ] generate an example where the two graphs are not matched and use that for the tutorial
- [ ] make sure all plots have axes labels

body: one thing to consider is whether the nonpar should eat graphs or embeddings (or either?). i occasionally find myself in the need of having to use it on the latter, and my workaround has been to go into source code and comment out the embedding, which is suboptiomal at best.

@alyakin314 a few comments: 
- talked to MSR engineers today, don't think we should wait for progress with merging to do this. We can set whatever API makes the most sense on our own, and then pass it off to whatever repo (possibly with a few cosmetic changes, but likely not much)
- I agree that these algos should be able to eat embeddings. Another option would be to allow a user to pass in an `embed_kws` dict but I hesitate to do that till we have a good use case for that. 
- Possible APIs: 
    1. classes, like they are now
    2. functions that return some kind of result object
    3. functions that return pval, tstat, and dictionary of anything else. 
My current preference, though I could be convinced otherwise, is to go with 3. I think this matches API of other tests better, I haven't been able to think of a use case where one needs to take the test object, modify it, and call another method. And there's not that much data to keep track of. It would also alleviate issues we talked about in #380 which would take more restructuring to fit if we keep as a class. 

Lmk your thoughts, I see this as one of the main tasks we can get done on our own while we wait for the merger into Microsoft to really happen
w.r.t. bullet point 2, I don't want that to hold anything up as far as the API goes. Can always add that in later no matter what we choose

- the nonpar test paper has << 100 citations, so it would be uneasy to pass it off to another repo any time soon. furthremore, we import hyppo, which imports joblib and other things, so we are significantly higher level than that allowed of scipy, and maybe even sklearn. this is just something to keep in mind.
- Youngser said that he'd also prefer using embeddings to be an option, by the way. i agree that hypothetically allowing to parametrize every step of the embedding and passing them as kwargs achieves the same job, but that just feels like an overcomplication stemmed from holding onto how we implemented it originally and keeping it consistent with lpt. i probably wouldn't even mind if eating embeddings would be the only option, because anything we include to embed can be done in a couple of other calls. on the other hand, people less familiar with graphs might want to get away with just a single function call if they have little idea of what's going on.
- notes on possible API's: 
  - im strongly leaning towards it being a function, but not settled on the return type.
  - if by return object you mean a custom thing with methods (so that we would end up with the same thing we usually call `ldt`, but instead of a user explicitly instantiating it, it would be done internally), i strongly oppose it. whereas, if by return object you mean a dict-like thing, then the named tuples that you hate so much actually cover your bullet points 2 and 3, because you can both assign them as `p_value, stat, _ = `, or extract as `object['p_value']`.
  - i am not yet fully sold on the fact that we should always return all three. 
  - also, something i want to mention is - i highly discourage anyone to use the statistic obtained from nonpar for anything, other than comparing it with statistics generated from the permutation of the same sample. so obtaining the p-value or plotting the null and the sample stat is okay, but using it for clustering, graph matching, etc. is most likely wrong. that's especially important if the backend test is done via exact equivalence, but really, it is almost always true that comparing the stats between two pairs of graphs is apples to oranges.
  - i wanted to ask you something regarding this: i believe you once sent a python package that had a lot of hypothesis tests implemented in it to slack, many of those tests are transferred from R. i've been trying to find it either via google or slack search and have failed so far. you won't happen to remember what it's called?

> * the nonpar test paper has << 100 citations, so it would be uneasy to pass it off to another repo any time soon. furthremore, we import hyppo, which imports joblib and other things, so we are significantly higher level than that allowed of scipy, and maybe even sklearn. this is just something to keep in mind.

I don't think we plan on exporting the inference stuff, this is the most graspy specific thing about the whole package IMO

> * Youngser said that he'd also prefer using embeddings to be an option, by the way. i agree that hypothetically allowing to parametrize every step of the embedding and passing them as kwargs achieves the same job, but that just feels like an overcomplication stemmed from holding onto how we implemented it originally and keeping it consistent with lpt. i probably wouldn't even mind if eating embeddings would be the only option, because anything we include to embed can be done in a couple of other calls. on the other hand, people less familiar with graphs might want to get away with just a single function call if they have little idea of what's going on.

Agree and agree. kwargs maybe someday, it is more complicated for sure. the one caveat is it probably makes more sense to go that route for the LPT because that test is doing repeated embedding calls, probably makes sense for all of them to use the same parameters. For LDT i have no issue with embeddings being passed.  

> * notes on possible API's:
>   
>   * im strongly leaning towards it being a function, but not settled on the return type.
>   * if by return object you mean a custom thing with methods (so that we would end up with the same thing we usually call `ldt`, but instead of a user explicitly instantiating it, it would be done internally), i strongly oppose it. whereas, if by return object you mean a dict-like thing, then the named tuples that you hate so much actually cover your bullet points 2 and 3, because you can both assign them as `p_value, stat, _ = `, or extract as `object['p_value']`.

I am ok with dict like thing, or tuple, including named tuples. What I meant was that some stuff in scipy returns a `result` object like this https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.OptimizeResult.html not for stats specifically as far as I know. But this kind of thing is what I meant by returning a custom object, which I'm not a fan of. 

>   * i am not yet fully sold on the fact that we should always return all three.

thoughts on this scheme https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.multiscale_graphcorr.html

>   * also, something i want to mention is - i highly discourage anyone to use the statistic obtained from nonpar for anything, other than comparing it with statistics generated from the permutation of the same sample. so obtaining the p-value or plotting the null and the sample stat is okay, but using it for clustering, graph matching, etc. is most likely wrong. that's especially important if the backend test is done via exact equivalence, but really, it is almost always true that comparing the stats between two pairs of graphs is apples to oranges.

fair enough, maybe worth talking about in the docs someday

>   * i wanted to ask you something regarding this: i believe you once sent a python package that had a lot of hypothesis tests implemented in it to slack, many of those tests are transferred from R. i've been trying to find it either via google or slack search and have failed so far. you won't happen to remember what it's called?

I believe you mean this https://pingouin-stats.org/ i had to do some digging too. easy name to forget, lol

issue.title: save metric kwarg as attribute
issue.body:
#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Metric kwarg should be stored as an attribute

body:
> > * the nonpar test paper has << 100 citations, so it would be uneasy to pass it off to another repo any time soon. furthremore, we import hyppo, which imports joblib and other things, so we are significantly higher level than that allowed of scipy, and maybe even sklearn. this is just something to keep in mind.
> 
> I don't think we plan on exporting the inference stuff, this is the most graspy specific thing about the whole package IMO

agreed.

> > * Youngser said that he'd also prefer using embeddings to be an option, by the way. i agree that hypothetically allowing to parametrize every step of the embedding and passing them as kwargs achieves the same job, but that just feels like an overcomplication stemmed from holding onto how we implemented it originally and keeping it consistent with lpt. i probably wouldn't even mind if eating embeddings would be the only option, because anything we include to embed can be done in a couple of other calls. on the other hand, people less familiar with graphs might want to get away with just a single function call if they have little idea of what's going on.
> 
> Agree and agree. kwargs maybe someday, it is more complicated for sure. the one caveat is it probably makes more sense to go that route for the LPT because that test is doing repeated embedding calls, probably makes sense for all of them to use the same parameters. For LDT i have no issue with embeddings being passed.

could you elaborate on repeated embedding calls? i found a total of 1:
https://github.com/neurodata/graspy/blob/0f4441ddc8dc09840147fed0f33f7c6be2dedb30/graspy/inference/latent_position_test.py#L206

> > * notes on possible API's:
> >   
> >   * im strongly leaning towards it being a function, but not settled on the return type.
> >   * if by return object you mean a custom thing with methods (so that we would end up with the same thing we usually call `ldt`, but instead of a user explicitly instantiating it, it would be done internally), i strongly oppose it. whereas, if by return object you mean a dict-like thing, then the named tuples that you hate so much actually cover your bullet points 2 and 3, because you can both assign them as `p_value, stat, _ = `, or extract as `object['p_value']`.
> 
> I am ok with dict like thing, or tuple, including named tuples. What I meant was that some stuff in scipy returns a `result` object like this https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.OptimizeResult.html not for stats specifically as far as I know. But this kind of thing is what I meant by returning a custom object, which I'm not a fan of.

yeah, not a fan of this either. feels like a clunky intermediate between a dict and an sklearn object.

> > * i am not yet fully sold on the fact that we should always return all three.
> 
> thoughts on this scheme https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.multiscale_graphcorr.html

will address this in a little bit.

> > * also, something i want to mention is - i highly discourage anyone to use the statistic obtained from nonpar for anything, other than comparing it with statistics generated from the permutation of the same sample. so obtaining the p-value or plotting the null and the sample stat is okay, but using it for clustering, graph matching, etc. is most likely wrong. that's especially important if the backend test is done via exact equivalence, but really, it is almost always true that comparing the stats between two pairs of graphs is apples to oranges.
> 
> fair enough, maybe worth talking about in the docs someday

sure.

> > * i wanted to ask you something regarding this: i believe you once sent a python package that had a lot of hypothesis tests implemented in it to slack, many of those tests are transferred from R. i've been trying to find it either via google or slack search and have failed so far. you won't happen to remember what it's called?
> 
> I believe you mean this https://pingouin-stats.org/ i had to do some digging too. easy name to forget, lol

yeah, this one. thanks a lot; should be easier to find given how many things they have implemented.

**scipy:**

**statsmodels:** (may have missed a couple here)

1 / 28

statistic+p-value+something else:
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.acorr_ljungbox.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.acorr_ljungbox
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.acorr_lm.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.acorr_lm

https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.het_goldfeldquandt.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.het_goldfeldquandt
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.het_white.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.het_white  (specifically statistic+p_value for one test, and statistic+p_value for another test)
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.spec_white.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.spec_white (stat+pvalue+dof)
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.linear_lm.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.linear_lm (specifically statistic+p_value for one test, and results tuple for another test)
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.sandbox.stats.runs.symmetry_bowker.html#statsmodels.sandbox.stats.runs.symmetry_bowker (stat+pvalue+dof)
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.sandbox.stats.runs.median_test_ksample.html#statsmodels.sandbox.stats.runs.median_test_ksample (huh?)
11 / 28

something weird:
https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.linear_reset.html#statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.linear_reset
1 / 28

afore mentioned pinguin always returns a dataframe. not a fan. prob needs not any further discussion.

i've looked through scipy and statsmodels, as you see above. most tests only return statistic+p_value, but they don't really have much else to return , to be fair. maybe degrees of freedom, but not returning that is a small loss compared to having interchangeable syntax. unlike us, where having an access to the null distribution seems important. 

a couple of statsmodel things have variable output, and none of scipy. for some reason, i expected this to be more prevalent, probably because i've seen this approach in sorting or something like that. i guess people share Dwayne's concerns about variable output lengths.

with this in mind, i now do not mind having it as

`stat, p_value, dict_of_things = latent_distribution_test(X, Y, **kwargs)`

what goes into dict_of_things other than the null distirbution? d_hat? matrix Q if alignment was performed? what else?

> could you elaborate on repeated embedding calls? i found a total of 1:

this one is in a for loop 
https://github.com/neurodata/graspy/blob/0f4441ddc8dc09840147fed0f33f7c6be2dedb30/graspy/inference/latent_position_test.py#L137

> what goes into dict_of_things other than the null distirbution? d_hat? matrix Q if alignment was performed? what else?

number of fitted components, since that could have been `None` from the user? 

Can't think of anything else off of the top of my head.

i have no objection to 
`stat, p_value, dict_of_things = latent_distribution_test(X, Y, **kwargs)`

> > what goes into dict_of_things other than the null distirbution? d_hat? matrix Q if alignment was performed? what else?
> 
> number of fitted components, since that could have been `None` from the user?
> 
> Can't think of anything else off of the top of my head.

this is what i mean by d_hat

> > could you elaborate on repeated embedding calls? i found a total of 1:
> 
> this one is in a for loop
> https://github.com/neurodata/graspy/blob/0f4441ddc8dc09840147fed0f33f7c6be2dedb30/graspy/inference/latent_position_test.py#L137

u're very much right. don't know how i missed that boi. i'll think about it.

> i have no objection to
> `stat, p_value, dict_of_things = latent_distribution_test(X, Y, **kwargs)`

neither do i, so let's settle on this.

issue.title: passing an embedding to LatentDistributionTest.fit()
issue.body:
#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
added an option to pass an embedding instead of a full graph to nonpar.
briefly mentioned this in #375 .
temporary measure to use this until the proper api change into a funciton

#### Any other comments?
passing pass_graph to fit seems like a more appropriate thing than being an argument to the instantiation
fully backward-compatible as the default is unaffected
had to overload the fit_predict abstract method

issue.title: Enable passing of embeddings to LatentDistributionTest
issue.body:
### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
added an option to pass an embedding instead of a full graph to nonpar.
briefly mentioned this in #375 .
temporary measure to use this until the proper api change into a function

### Any other comments?
fully backward-compatible as the default is unaffected
had to overload the fit_predict abstract method
this replaces #399 (with clean history)

body: @bdpedigo i actually don't mind delegating this to ndd.
